comments.commentBody: I stayed many nights at the Windsor over a one month period in Egypt. I loved it. The staff is great, the neighborhood is quiet yet not far from the metro and lots of small eateries nearby. And, yes, the hotel bar is fantastic. After a day in Cairo I would have afternoon tea in this treasure of a room. My room was spare but comfortable. Most importantly it was quiet. I would not think of staying anywhere else when I go back.
This 360 degree turn on Robinson is why no one should complaint when athletes squeeze as much $$$ from teams.

"The Knicks had gone 1-9 to start the season with Robinson in the rotation."

If you check the records on this, I think you'll find that Nate missed games 4 through 9 due to an injury, so he really wasn't in the rotation for those games.
Go Knicks and Lil' Nate!!! Kryptonite baby!(seriously though, Dwight Howard should have won the Slam Dunk competition)

I travel a lot. I frequent 5 star hotels for business and I travel with family often finding value. I struck gold. This is BY FAR/HANDS DOWN the best value for your money ANYWHERE I have been in the world. Let me explain:

1) I paid 60 euros a night for a double room ($75)
2) The location is fantastic as it is only 5 minutes walk to Sultanahmet (Blue Mosque), Hagia Sopia and Topkapi Palace!
3) I was traveling with my 9 month old son. The staff went above the call of duty and bought a new cot and a baby bathtub. I told them it wasnt necessary but they still went ahead an got it. No five star hotel has done that (without paying for it)
4) Breakfast is superb. Great selection and lots to eat. Hot omelletes as well.
5) We also were brought our buffet plates up to the terrace where you have a superb view (unobstructed) of the Blue mosque and the Sea of Marmara. Beautiful.
6) Every afternoon were were asked for tea or coffee (complimentary) and were delivered it within 3 minutes each day after ordering with a nice surprise of a plate of cookies/biscotti. Fantastic.
8) The hotel is owned by an artichetct and it shoes. It is renovated beautifully and it is well decorated and looks new. The bathrooms are small, but adequate, clean and nice looking.
9) Free internet-Free turkish bath(hammam)
10) 2way free transfer to airport

I am forgetting a lot of things, but I am very satisfied with this stay. I would recommend this place to any everyone.

The only one drawback to this hotel is that if you are wishing for a livelier evening and nightlife, you have to head out to the new part of Istanbul to Beyoglu. Sometimes we taxi'd it and sometimes we took the tram. But this isnt the hotel's fault. It was my choice to stay in Sultanahmet..
Eva NYC

www.hotelsultanhan.com

Should you be in Tucson and decide to drive south to Tubac -- at some point you will have to leave the Interstate and get on the Frontage Road.  If you like spice, visit Santa Cruz Spice Factory in Tumacacori (and don't miss the mission on the other side of the road).  For eats, look for the big chicken -- east side of the road as you motor south.  Leave room for a fruit burro.

The service was terrible to start. Reached there at 7PM, ordered at 7:15, food did not arrive until 8:30. The restaurant was NOT crowded. So the food came late, and the waiters didn't refill our water for nearly 20 minutes the first time; another patron pulled over one of the waiters and had to ask for more water. In addition, we ordered one of the dishes mild since my brother has sensitivities towards spicy food. Yet, that dish arrived with chopped chili peppers.

We were not only ones with problems; as we entered, a couple got up from their meal, told the waiter the service was inexcusable, and left. Behind us, a wonderful old couple waited nearly as long as we did for their food. 

The food itself was not above average, and it certainly does not warrant the hefty price tag. The service was disgusting. 

Avoid at all costs!

Even though it is understandable that the Iraqis are outraged, the judge deserves praise for upholding the law despite the international political pressure.  Given the serious prosecutorial misconduct, amply documented, he had no choice but to dismiss,

Marines rock. ANGLICO Marines are outstanding, Still after 60+ years they remain a unique and critical element of our fighting force, despite much resentment of the independent character of the unit.

Freedom isn't free, and families too pay the price.

The US should never have upset the rickety order  that characterized Iraq under Saddam Hussein. But because we began a stupid war under false pretenses is no excuse for killing Christians in Iraq. Blowing up churches in Iraq should be regarded as no more acceptable than blowing up mosques in Denmark or Spain would be.

Blackwater, Xe or whatever they want to call themselves are the greatest terrorist threat to our country. Do they have so much power that they can get those murderers off scott free. The prosecutors must have been in on the deal to have done such a screwed up job. These terrorists guard half our leaders. Why does this administration deal with these thugs? Another huge disappointment from Obama. He has made enormous contracts with Xe knowing about their Nazi ways. Too bad for America. We certainly choose to take the low road. It's part of our race to the bottom.

During my recent trips to Mumbai I visited Britannia, Mahesh Lunch Home and a few more non-veg restaurants. For the sea-food lovers there are two more very good options - Goa Portuguesa Restaurant and Diva Maharashtracha. Both are located near Hinduja Hospital - Mahim (central Mumbai) and I found the Goan and Maharastrian (Konkani) sea-food better than Mahesh's which is Mangalorean and uses bit more tamarind. Britannia's Berry Pulav and Dhan Sakh were fantastic. Also discovered that the Britannia owners were my neighbors in Fort for many years. The trip to Mumbai would be incomplete if you do not taste the street food. A quick visit to Khau-Galli (Food Street) near Apna Bazaar - P.M. Road in Fort is worth to have snacks, Vada Paav or just to see the hustle and bustle during the lunch hours. It is also worth trying the 'Ganne Ka Juice' (Sugarcane Juice) and 'Aarey Energee' near the Gateway of India. The fresh (and most expensive) sugarcane juice is available at a stall on the left hand side between the Maharashtra Police Headquarters and Gateway monument.

I must defend my suggestion as much more than a gimmick. This does not affect who gets in and who doesn't, nor does it give one team an unfair advantage over their playoff opponent. Nor does it require the league to require teams to "compete".

The Saints aren't starting Brees this week.

My solution, brilliant in its simplicity, is that teams get rewarded with playoff positioning based on how they are playing in the period prior to the playoffs.

And this is far from a non-issue. It is a very real issue. It doesn't take much to come up with a scenario where a team can improve its playoff prospects by losing a game. That is an intolerable situation.

Now, if that team could lose their home playoff game, or be forced to play in the first round, then that game does indeed mean quite a lot. Conversely, the hottest teams going in earn the right to take a week off.

I bet if you ask the players, they'd say the idea of rewarding hot teams with playoff position has merit, and I think if you ask anybody, they would say that every game of the season will be meaningful in all but the very rarest cases, whereas the problem we are trying to solve happens not only annually but several times annually.

Please, wherever you stand on this suggestion, don't dismiss it as a gimmick.

I completely agree that the key matchup in this game is their front four against our offensive line.

Here's what I expect: Some counter-programming by Schott. Richardson and Jones in the backfield, but to pass protect while Sanchez probes the edges. If the Bengals are forced to send their safeties wide, that will open up the middle, and once the linebackers have to prevent the big pass play, that will leave a more fair fight for the running game.

So - edges downfield, then some middle passing, then the running game.

We'll see, of course, and it's equally possible that Rex will say "Stuff it in there" and go mano-a-mano. I've seen a lot of coaches run the ball and run the ball until they finally manage to move the chains, and only then allow some passing, once they've earned the defense's respect.

But wouldn't that also be playing into the Bengals hands? What they want to do - what every Jets opponent wants to do - is make Sanchez have to win or lose the game. So in other words their very game plan is to stop the run and force the Jets to pass.

So...beat them to the pass, so to speak. Pass the ball when they're expecting run, let Sanchez get into a groove, loosen up or at least spread the defense, then go one on one with that defensive line.

I would love to see us come out throwing. I would love to see us play with maximum bravado.

Just one thing: Please, no gadget plays. They never seem to work. Stuff those reverses in your bippy, Coach Schottenheimer.

Running backward does not suit this team.

The new chef, James Wong is creating some of the greatest food in California.. His menu is a creative use of local organic produce, the freshest seafood and meats with an attention to detail that verges on perfection.
His salad of mâché,roasted fig, and red hawk cheese from the cowgirl creamery in Point Reyes is a revelation. This is truly great art disguised as food. DLJ

I think I liked some of the non-theme wordplay even more than the theme, as clever as it was.

Like you, Pat, I liked "Coming-out party" and "It has an expiration date" very much, but the one that made me laugh out loud was 118-Down, "A little butter?" Totally threw me for a bit. I kid you not.
@cambiot:  you answered your own question, using the phrase pet peeve.  Think of pet as an adjective, like a pet project.

haha!! Patrick, your cartoon cracked me up! we did indeed toileth today, but we toilethed more yesterday (Saturday) :-)

fun puzzle!
With much embarrassment, must ask, does 5Across fall on second line and is answer "FOCUS"? And I'm completely blanked on 6A "Take to the altar."

One of my favorite acrostics to date. Beautifully constructed. Loved the poop clue hehe....
Almost had to go put on my winter coat as it all came together. Wonderfully evocative. I was lucky enough to travel to Norway a couple of years ago and in Oslo (which i loved!) got to climb onto the Fram and explore every inch of it....absolutely riveting stuff....so this acrostic really came alive for me - thanks!
cheers...

i think this is a knee-jerk reaction to the recession. everything in this country-from the malls, the advertising, the media, etc is designed to make people buy something, anything. right now it seems to be in 'fashion' to be 'cutting back' in 'these tough economic times'. ultimately people are still buying things they do not need as evidenced by an increase in holiday shopping. i would be interested to see the effects of this recession on long-term savings rates. if and when the jobs come back, i wonder if the 'i gottta have it' attitude comes back as well. i suspect it will.

Elevating experience over things??? What???

Wait until North Face hears about this one.

~A disgusted Park Slope mom

The first decade of this century will go down in American history as a time when Americans bought stuff they didn't need, with money they didn't have, to impress people they didn't like, while they're elected leaders used the twin pillars of fear and greed to remain in power.
Duh! Get over it America. Happiness is a warm puppy, not an SUV.

To quote California State Attorney General Edmund G (Jerry) Brown,
Less is More.
Ain't is so.
